title: Erdős Problem #190: Canonical Ramsey Number for Arithmetic Progressions
description: Estimate H(k), the smallest N guaranteeing either a monochromatic or rainbow k-term arithmetic progression in every coloring of {1,...,N}.

overview.historicalContext: This is a canonical Ramsey theory problem from Erdős-Graham [ErGr79, p.333; ErGr80, p.17]. Unlike van der Waerden numbers W(k) (which require monochromatic APs only), H(k) allows rainbow APs as an alternative 'win condition'. The existence of H(k) follows from Szemerédi's theorem: for N large enough, either pigeonhole forces a monochromatic AP, or the coloring uses enough colors for a rainbow AP. The known result H(k)^{1/k} → ∞ is relatively straightforward, but the stronger question H(k)^{1/k}/k → ∞ — equivalently, whether H(k) grows faster than k^k — remains open.
overview.problemStatement: Let H(k) denote the smallest N such that any finite coloring of {1,...,N} contains either a monochromatic k-term AP or a rainbow k-term AP (all different colors). Estimate H(k), and determine if H(k)^{1/k}/k → ∞.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines arithmetic progressions, monochromatic/rainbow colorings, the canonical property, and the H(k) function via Nat.find. Van der Waerden numbers W(k) are similarly defined. Known results (H(k)^{1/k} → ∞, H(k) ≤ W(k), lower bounds) are axioms. The main conjecture H(k)^{1/k}/k → ∞ is stated. A summary theorem combines the known results.
keyInsights: H(k) ≤ W(k) because rainbow APs provide an easier 'win condition' than monochromatic only
H(k)^{1/k} → ∞ is known — the k-th root grows without bound
Whether H(k)^{1/k}/k → ∞ (equivalently H(k) > k^k eventually) is open
Rainbow and monochromatic conditions compete via the pigeonhole principle
Existence of H(k) follows from Szemerédi's theorem on APs in dense sets

sections.title: Part 1: Arithmetic Progressions
sections.summary: Definition of k-term arithmetic progressions as sets {a, a+d, ..., a+(k-1)d} and as function sequences.

sections.title: Part 2: Colorings
sections.summary: Colorings of {1,...,N}, monochromatic sets (all same color), and rainbow sets (all distinct colors).

sections.title: Part 3: The Canonical Property
sections.summary: A coloring has the canonical property for k-APs if it contains a monochromatic OR rainbow k-AP.

sections.title: Part 4: The H(k) Function
sections.summary: H(k) defined via Nat.find as the minimum N guaranteeing the canonical property. Existence, specification, and minimality axioms.

sections.title: Part 5: Relation to van der Waerden Numbers
sections.summary: Van der Waerden number W(k) defined via Nat.find. H(k) ≤ W(k) and H(k) ≥ k for k ≥ 3.

sections.title: Part 7: Small Cases
sections.summary: Bounds on small values: H(3) ≤ 10, H(4) ≤ 100.

sections.title: Part 8: Connections
sections.summary: Connection to Szemerédi's theorem (density → existence) and canonical vs standard Ramsey theory.

sections.title: Part 9: Why This Is Hard
sections.summary: The challenge of precise asymptotics: interplay between monochromatic and rainbow conditions via pigeonhole.

sections.title: Part 10: Summary
sections.summary: H_pos axiom, summary theorem combining H(k) > 0 and H(k)^{1/k} → ∞. Status: OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #190 asks for bounds on H(k), the canonical Ramsey number for k-APs. H(k) is the smallest N where every coloring of {1,...,N} yields a monochromatic or rainbow k-AP. The known result H(k)^{1/k} → ∞ is formalized; the open question H(k)^{1/k}/k → ∞ is stated as the main conjecture.
conclusion.implications: Better bounds on H(k) would illuminate the structure of arithmetic progressions in colored sets and the balance between monochromatic and rainbow patterns in canonical Ramsey theory.
openQuestions: What are tight bounds on H(k) for specific small k?
How does H(k) compare to other canonical Ramsey numbers?
What is the precise relationship between H(k) and the Hales-Jewett numbers?
